title: Nigeria ruling party candidate takes early election lead
description: With 11 of Nigeria's 36 states having been reported as of Monday evening, ruling party candidate Bola Tinubu was leading with 46% of the 6.7 million counted votes so far. But the two leading opposition parties claimed there were disparities between the results and what their representatives learned at the polling stations.

title: French officials probe rape accusation against PSG's Hakimi
description: French prosecutors have opened a preliminary investigation into a rape accusation against Paris Saint-Germain defender Achraf Hakimi, a judicial official said on Monday.

title: Macron plans 'noticeable reduction' of French troops in Africa
description: The French president was speaking ahead of a four-nation tour of central African countries. Paris has fallen out with new military authorities in Mali and Burkina Faso.

title: How a Portuguese citizenship loophole became a door into the EU
description: A 2013 law was supposed to make it easier for descendants of expelled Portuguese Jews to obtain citizenship. But its loose rules allowed a lucrative business to emerge, which is now at the heart of a judicial investigation.

title: 'Best chef in the world' Guy Savoy stripped of Michelin star
description: The 69-year-old has held Michelin's top three-star status since 2002 for his Monnaie de Paris restaurant overlooking the Seine.

title: In Northern Ireland, new border protocol still divides
description: The British government hopes that the agreement negotiated Monday with the European Union will ease inter-communal tensions in the province that has been without a government for a year.

title: Jean Pisani-Ferry: 'The US Inflation Reduction Act raises questions about the EU's climate strategy'
description: The American climate policy poses a serious competitiveness problem for Europe, which must avoid both the rut of protectionism and naivety, writes the economist.

title: Tunisia seeks to reassure migrants after president's remarks
description: President Kais Saied had called for 'urgent measures' against 'hordes' of sub-Saharan migrants.

title: World Bank estimates Turkey quake damage at $34 billion
description: The amount doesn't account for the costs of reconstruction that were 'potentially twice as large,' according to the institution.

title: Erdogan asks forgiveness for rescue delays after Turkey quake
description: The Turkish president, who is seeking reelection, has received strong criticsm from survivors of the deadily natural disaster.

title: Betty Boothroyd, UK's first female House of Commons speaker, dies at 93
description: Boothroyd presided over the often raucous debates with no-nonsense humor between 1992 and 2000.

title: UK and EU clinch Brexit deal over Northern Ireland trade
description: Rishi Sunak and Ursula von der Leyen met to finalize an agreement on the Northern Ireland Protocol, a key aspect of the UK's post-Brexit relationship with its European partners.

title: Israel sends additional troops to West Bank after settler rampage
description: The responses to the rampage laid bare some rifts in Israel's new right-wing government.

title: How the head of the Brittany region lobbies the EU
description: Loïg Chesnais-Girard, who was elected on the slogan 'More Brittany, less Paris', defends his region's interests directly with European institutions.

title: Two dead in Russian drone attack in west Ukraine
description: The victims in Monday's attack in Khmelnytskyi were a 21-year-old and 31-year-old.

title: Nigeria election: Three parties each claim lead in presidential race
description: Bola Tinubu, Atiku Abubakar and Peter Obi were all declared to be on a winning path by their respective parties. Results have only been only announced in one of the 36 states.

title: France and Germany call for de-escalation in West Bank
description: A foreign ministry spokesperson said it was 'urgent' the tense situation in the occupied West Bank is not inflamed, while France 'condemned' the violence.

title: The unexpected fall of Ukraine's oligarchs
description: Since the start of the Russian invasion, the wealthy businessmen who reigned over the country for 30 years have lost their influence. It could be a turning point for Ukraine.

title: Germany must continue its transformation
description: A year ago, shaken by the invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a historic turning point for his country: the 'Zeitenwende', or new era. Much has been accomplished. European partners expect Germany to make use of this momentum.

title: Finding the true colors of the 'Lady and the Unicorn' tapestry
description: Researchers are trying to find the medieval recipes for the dyes used in the six famous tapestries of the Musée de Cluny in Paris.

title: Possible extradition of Italian anti-globalization activist raises specter of fascist law
description: Italy is calling on France to extradite an activist sentenced to over 12 years in prison for his participation in anti-G8 demonstrations in Genoa in 2001 – on the grounds of a law against 'devastation and looting' dating from the Mussolini era.

title: At least 60 migrants drown off Italian coast after boat capsizes
description: After Sunday's tragic incident off the coast of Calabria, the debate about asylum reform in the European Union has been reopened.

title: Turkey to hold NATO bid talks with Sweden, Finland in March
description: Bids to join NATO must be ratified by all members of the alliance, of which Turkey is a member.

title: A visit to Lviv's cemetery and its freshly dug war graves
description: The military cemetery opened in Lviv at the beginning of the Russian invasion of Ukraine already contains hundreds of graves, with a capacity ten times greater.

title: 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' dominates at SAG Awards
description: The absurdist sci-fi comedy continued its dominance of this year's Hollywood award shows by earning top honors from the Screen Actors Guild on Sunday. The SAG Awards are considered one of the most reliable Oscar bellwethers.

title: Organic farming is left behind in French government's aid to agricultural industry
description: Organic farming is losing ground and receiving little support, while conventional farming benefits from hundreds of millions of euros in aid.

title: François Hadji-Lazaro, founder of the groups Pigalle and Les Garçons Bouchers, is dead at 66
description: The musician, a unique figure of French alternative rock who was also an actor and music producer, died Saturday, February 25.

title: Kais Saied's Tunisia, a fading star
description: The end of the Tunisian 'spring' is now in sight. Saied's autocratic and repressive regime has severely damaged the country's international reputation.

title: War in Ukraine: 'Providing the Russian population with professional, diversified and non-warlike information is one of the keys to the conflict'
description: Reporters Without Borders Secretary General Christophe Deloire and Denis Diderot Committee members André Lange and Jim Phillipoff plead for the creation of a range of independent Russian and international Russian-speaking channels via the Eutelstat satellite.

title: Cyprus, a dead end for migrants seeking asylum in Europe
description: Migrants generally arrive on the northern side of the island of Cyprus which is only recognized by Turkey. They then wait in limbo after applying for asylum in the Republic, in the hope of being able to continue their journey in the EU.

title: 'West Side Story' producer Walter Mirisch dies aged 101
description: The famous film producer who oversaw such classics as 'Some Like It Hot' and 'The Pink Panther,' has died of natural causes, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said Saturday.

title: Farmers, a declining political force in France
description: Although French MPs continue to flock to the Salon de l'Agriculture, France's agricultural show, every year, the influence of this category of the population has waned, explains 'Le Monde' journalist Elsa Conesa in her column.
